questions.question: The spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called
questions.explanation: A receptive field is the area of the body or environment where a stimulus can produce a response in a particular sensory neuron or group of neurons.

questions.question: The phasic receptor is
questions.explanation: Meissner's corpuscles are phasic (rapidly adapting) receptors.Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, and muscle spindle are tonic (slowly adapting) receptors.

questions.question: You are doing a CNS examination of a patient with a spinal injury. At which of the followingsites would the distance of two-point discrimination be greatest?
questions.explanation: The distance of two-point discrimination is greatest at the back of the scapula.217The relative tactile acuity of a given region can be determined by the two-point discriminationtest. Here, calipers are used to determine the minimum distance between the two points whichcan be perceived as two points. Greater the density of receptors → Smaller the receptive field →More precise the localization.For e.g., Stimulus points on the back, for instance, must be separated by at least 65 mm beforethey can be distinguished as separate, whereas on the fingertips two stimuli are recognized if theyare separated by as little as 2 mm. The lips have the greatest acuity (two-point discriminationthreshold ~1 mm).Clinical significance:Blind individuals benefit from the tactile acuity of fingertips to facilitate the ability to readBraille. The dots forming Braille symbols are separated by 2.5 mm.Two-point discrimination is used to test the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus)system.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the nature of the sensory receptor given below:
questions.explanation: The sensory receptor shown in the above image is Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is arapidly adapting receptor and is an encapsulated receptor.When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequencyof the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is knownas receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidlyor slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow adapting receptors (tonic).

questions.question: Which of the following classification of receptors is the same?
questions.explanation: Mechanoreceptors and exteroceptors have the same classification of receptors.Exteroceptors are concerned with the external environment or receptors which receives externalstimuli. Mechanoreceptors are cutaneous receptors for touch and pressure. Thusmechanoreceptors can be considered to be exteroceptors.Nociceptors are pain receptors which detect physical and chemical damage occuring in the tissue.Interoceptors are concerned with the internal environment.Chemoreceptors are receptors stimulated by a change in the chemical composition of theenvironment in which they are located. These include receptors for taste and smell as well asvisceral receptors such as those sensitive to changes in the plasma level of O2, pH, and osmolality.Teleceptors (distance receivers) are concerned with events at a distance, example -photoreceptors.Proprioceptors provide information about the position of the body in space at any given instant.218

questions.question: The most potent algogenic substance is
questions.explanation: Bradykinin is the most potent algogenic substance.An algogenic substance is a chemical released at the site of injury which mediates pain. Theseinclude bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolyticenzymes.Prostaglandins and substance P enhance the sensitivity of pain endings but do not directly excitethem.Note: This is a controversial questionAccording to Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page 622-"One chemical that seems to be more painful than others is bradykinin. Researchers havesuggested that bradykinin might be the agent most responsible for causing pain after tissuedamage."Hence, bradykinin is the better answer (not serotonin)

questions.question: Vanilloid receptors are activated by all except
questions.explanation: Vanilloid receptors are not activated by vibration.Vanilloid receptors or TRPV1 (transient receptor potential vanilloid1) receptors are a partof family of nonselective cation channels called transient receptor potential (TRP) channels. Thesechannels respond to intense heat, acids, and chemicals such as capsaicin.

questions.question: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to
questions.explanation: Weber-Fechner Law states that the magnitude of sensation felt is proportionate to the log of theintensity of the stimulus.Other Laws in Physiology:•⚫ Doctrine of specific nerve energies - When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ arestimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized no matter how orwhere along the pathway the activity is initiated.•Law of projection - No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its courseto the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor. Thisprinciple is called the law of projection.

questions.question: A patient's right leg was amputated because it was unsalvageable after the motor vehicleaccident. After 2 weeks of her surgery, she started feeling episodes of severe pain in theamputated area. This pain is most likely based on which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation: This patient is having phantom limb pain. This pain is based on cortical plasticity.Cortical structures are capable of reorganization after the loss of a body part. The corticalrepresentation of the neighboring parts spreads into the cortical area that was formerly occupiedby the representation of the amputated part. This is called cortical plasticity leads to thephenomenon of phantom limb pain

questions.question: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is
questions.explanation: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is allodynia.Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus. An example of primaryhyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of theskin pain endings by local tissue products released due to burns — histamine, prostaglandins, andothers.Causalgia is a type of neuropathic pain.-

questions.question: Which of the following is true about anandamide?213

options.C: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray

questions.explanation: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray and other areas concernedwith pain.There are 2 types of endogenous cannabinoids: 2-arachidonyl glycerol and Anandamide. Theybind to CB1 and CB2 receptors. They have an anti-nociceptive effect.221Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray inhibit transmission innociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla(Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releasesendogenous opiates.

options.C: It is mediated by B fibers

questions.question: Pain insensitive structure is
questions.explanation: Alveoli are pain insensitive structures. Alveoli of lungs and parenchyma of liver are almostcompletely insensitive to the pain of any type.However, the liver capsule is extremely sensitive to both direct trauma and stretch. The bile ducts,arterial walls, bronchi and the parietal pleura are very sensitive to pain.

questions.question: A patient with chronic pain is undergoing transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation for painrelief. What is the basis of this procedure?
questions.explanation: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) of pain relief is based on the gate theory ofpain. This method uses electrodes to activate A° and Aẞ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.222The relief may result from inhibition of pain pathways (Inhibition of C fibers and A-delta fibers) inthe dorsal horn gate, by stimulation of large-diameter touch-pressure afferents(A-beta fibers). Thisis called the gate-control hypothesis.Interesting clinical application: Touching or shaking an injured area decreases the pain due to theinjury. Stimulation with an electric vibrator at the site of pain also gives some relief.The same mechanism is probably responsible for the efficacy of counterirritants. Stimulation ofthe skin over an area of visceral inflammation produces some relief of the pain due to the visceraldisease. The old-fashioned mustard plaster works on this principle.Gate control mechanism of painmodulationA-delta and C fibers(Nociceptive)A-beta fibers(Nonnociceptive)Cerebral cortexOMARROWThalamusInhibitoryinterneuron

questions.question: Primary cutaneous hyperalgesia214

options.A: Develops in the normal skin region around the area of flare
options.B: Is an abnormal condition in the skin in which painful stimuli become less severe
options.C: Is due to changes in threshold of pain receptors
options.D: Is associated with throbbing type of pain

questions.explanation: •Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus.Hyperalgesia and allodynia signify increased sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers.• Causes of hyperalgesia• The excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors, which is called primary hyperalgesia• Facilitation of sensory transmission, which is called secondary hyperalgesia.An example of primary hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which resultsfrom sensitization of the skin pain endings, by local tissue products from the burn — histamine,prostaglandins, and others.Secondary hyperalgesia frequently results from lesions in the spinal cord or the thalamus.

questions.question: The transient receptor potential (TRP) channel that is most active at normal skin temperatureis
questions.explanation: At normal skin temperatures, TRPV3 is the most active receptor.223

questions.question: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia,how do you best measure his temperature?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the corebody temperature.During low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highlymisleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperaturesInfrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representativeof core body temperature. However, more often the thermometer is not inserted adequately or forsafety reasons, they are manufactured in such a way that they do not reach deep into the earcanal, or the ear canal contains cerumen which can disturb the measurement. Hence the infraredthermometer more commonly delivers the temperature of ear canal cerumen and hence not areliable method of measuring the core body temperature.224
